name: K-good
statement: We say that a positive integer $$$n$$$ is $$$k$$$-good for some positive integer $$$k$$$ if $$$n$$$ can be expressed as a sum of $$$k$$$ positive integers which give $$$k$$$ distinct remainders when divided by $$$k$$$. Given a positive integer $$$n$$$, find some $$$k \geq 2$$$ so that $$$n$$$ is $$$k$$$-good or tell that such a $$$k$$$ does not exist.
inputFormat: The input consists of multiple test cases. The first line contains a single integer $$$t$$$ ($$$1 \leq t \leq 10^5$$$) â€” the number of test cases. Each test case consists of one line with an integer $$$n$$$ ($$$2 \leq n \leq 10^{18}$$$).
outputFormat: For each test case, print a line with a value of $$$k$$$ such that $$$n$$$ is $$$k$$$-good ($$$k \geq 2$$$), or $$$-1$$$ if $$$n$$$ is not $$$k$$$-good for any $$$k$$$. If there are multiple valid values of $$$k$$$, you can print any of them.
